title: Acoustic Neuroma
chief_complaint: I have had hearing loss in my left ear for about a year and a half that seems to come and go. Recently the feeling of fullness stopped, but now I have a ringing sound in that ear.

problem_summary.course: Progressive and fluctuating. Treated with steroids 2 months prior with no improvement. 6 weeks prior, aural fullness resolved but hearing loss persisted and tinnitus began.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Unilateral tinnitus (left). Denies otalgia, otorrhea, dizziness.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Persistent hearing loss despite resolution of fullness.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking diagnosis after failed steroid treatment.

history.present_illness: Patient reports progressive, fluctuating hearing loss in the left ear with aural fullness for 1.5 years. 2 months ago, treated by urgent care with steroids (no improvement). 6 weeks ago, sudden relief in fullness, but loss persisted and tinnitus started.
history.noise_exposure_history: 10-year history of military service and recreational noise exposure involving rifles held on the right shoulder.
history.prior_management: Consulted urgent care physician 2 months prior; prescribed steroids which were ineffective.
history.patient_goals: Determine cause of left ear symptoms.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear within normal limits (250-8000 Hz). Left ear shows mild to moderate mid- to high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss (1500-6000 Hz) with recovery to normal at 8000 Hz.

numeric_results.Left_Ear_Thresholds: Normal (0-15 dB) at 250-1000 Hz; dropping to ~40-50 dB HL at 2000-4000 Hz; recovery to ~15 dB HL at 8000 Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal ability to recognize speech bilaterally. No significant rollover observed.

numeric_results.WRS_Right: 100% at 80 dB HL, 100% at 95 dB HL
numeric_results.WRS_Left: 100% at 80 dB HL, 100% at 95 dB HL

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal Type A tympanograms bilaterally. Slight positive pressure but within normal range.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Mostly normal, but elevated thresholds observed for left ear stimulation at higher frequencies.

numeric_results.Stim_Left_Ipsi: Normal at 500/1k; Elevated (105 dB) at 2k; Elevated/Absent (105 dB) at 4k

tests.name: Electrocochleography (ECoG)
tests.key_findings: Robust waveforms with normal latencies and SP/AP ratios. Ruled out Meniere's disease/excess fluid.

history.present_illness: Follow-up after audiological evaluation revealed asymmetry.

tests.name: MRI
tests.key_findings: Confirmed presence of a large Acoustic Neuroma (AN) pressing against the left middle cerebellar peduncle.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a mild-to-moderate mid-to-high frequency sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear, contrasting with normal hearing in the right ear. Despite the asymmetry, speech recognition scores are excellent (100%) bilaterally with no rollover. Acoustic reflexes are elevated in the left ear at high frequencies, and MRI imaging confirmed a 1.5 cm acoustic neuroma on the left side.
counseling_points: The MRI has confirmed a benign growth called an Acoustic Neuroma (or Vestibular Schwannoma) on your hearing nerve.
Although 'tumor' sounds scary, these are typically slow-growing and not cancerous. However, it is occupying space and pressing on the nerve, which explains your hearing loss and tinnitus.
Your speech understanding is excellent right now, which is a very positive sign.
Treatment options include active surveillance (monitoring), radiation therapy, or microsurgery. Since you are currently undecided, we will support you as you discuss these options with your surgeon.
notes_for_actor: You are a 31-year-old male with a military background.
You are generally healthy but frustrated by the left ear hearing loss and ringing.
You are anxious about the diagnosis of a 'tumor' but relieved to have an answer after the steroids didn't work.
You are currently undecided on treatment (surgery vs. radiation vs. waiting) and may ask questions about the risks of each.
